I understand this type of informational video on a subject many people would be curious about, is an extreme version of a "what would happen?" video.  But the narrator treats the subject as if the whole idea isn't horrifying, but rather a scenario that a group of idiots who happened to get there hands on such a destructive device don't consider all the things that could go wrong & the impending devastating results that will occur.  Instead they say "but it would be so cool to to find out what happens."  It's ridiculous that the narrator concludes by saying "nothing would really happen, it wouldn't affect the tectonic plates, or volcanoes, it wouldn't cause huge waves or destructive weather, etc."  Such a foolish, child-like even, response.  Not to mention irresponsible.  How can it be said that such a test wouldn't have a drastic effects?  I mean, the destruction of marine life alone should prevent any educated human from making such ridiculous statements like "there would be no serious effects".  I'm not sure what you were trying to accomplish, but I wasn't impressed or intrigued.  But at least I know to steer clear of your videos from now on.

I've never heard such a ludicrous final determination.  The end result is NOT "nothing."  There would be lots of marine life exterminated from the radiation rising from the depths.  The ocean would disperse that radiation contaminating everything everywhere it goes.  Radiation would also get into the atmosphere and spread around the planet, regardless of the effect being measurable or not.  Even a .00000001 increase in radiation could mean some people and animals get cancer, that might not have.  This is an incredibly asinine premise let alone some fools actually trying to do it.  Until such time as we can simply beam up and travel a warp speeds to other habitable planets, we need to be careful about what we do to this planet.  After all, it is the only place in the universe where we can live.  Let's be more concerned about how to clean up the mess that humanity has already made of our only home.

Great in-depth analysis, but I think you forgot one important issue, landslides.   While the force of the blast would generally be contained to about a 1 km radius, if the bomb was on the floor of the Marianas Trench, then it should be within that distance from.the side of the trench.  So a large amount of force should be hitting the base sides of the trench.  This could trigger some truly massive underwater landslides given how deep the trench is.  There have been cases of large underwater landslides causing tsunamis before, and I'd wonder if thia type of situation could also cause one.  Figuring it out would take quite a bit a work though trying to figure out exactly how the side of the trench would respond and require information on the geometry of the specific area of the trench and information on the composition of the trench walls.

There have been nuclear detonations done in the Marianna Trench at 35,500 feet down. This is the deepest point on the planet. On the surface, there was a small shock wave that sounded like a repetitive hammering on the hull of the ship. 20 minutes later there were some hot bubbles of radioactive gas. The ocean had completely absorbed the blast of a 1.1 Megatone bomb, and only caused bubbles on the surface 30 minutes after the bang. Yeah, the ocean is big.

I'm wondering. For the detonator to work so deep in the ocean the body of the bomb would have to be a lot thicker to resist the water pressure. Wouldn't it additionally decrease the power of the explosion by a significant value?

Let me tell you what will actually happen.

A 3 ways (left, right, and up) shockwave in the 3-4 km range and that's approx 50% of the total deepness of the Mariana Trench. the pressure in the trench is eight tons per square inch and thousands of times greater and may crush any bone in the body of any living creature. that's like a caching grip from all sides if something is about to evade. so the TSAR BOMBA won't affect anything at all at our atmospheric level nor will affect the earth's crust in any harmful manner.
maybe, probably a 100+ TNT bomb would leave an impact and will be felt across a few hundred kilometers on the surface once exploded. but again, even all the power combined in the world if exploded in the Mariana Trench; won't do any harm to Earth's crust. it's impossible to penetrate the earth's crust or affect Lithosphere or Asthenosphere leave alone the Mantle/Outer/Inner core which is measured 6370 km while the total Mariana Trench height is 8 km.

Tsar-bomb would NOT cause massive radiation poisoning due to it's special construction. In ordinary nuclear bombs we use uranium-235 or plutonium-239 as a explosion material, which can cause harsh radiation pollution if the bomb construction is primitive and cause the radioactive material spread all around the explosion zone instead of exploding. In tsar bomb scientists used termonuclear reactions,products of which is not radioactive. The only source of radio-pollution in tsar-bomb were the initiators of thermonuclear reaction. Scientists came in the test field in two hours after the explosion and the background was only 1 milliroengten/hour, safe level.

This video lies. The radioactive isotopes produced will last for various different timescales - not least is strontium 90 which lasts for millions of year and plutonium and uranium which last for billions of years. These can enter the food chain and can cause cancer. Most of the internal land of the United States is radioactively contaminated because of the nuclear testing in Nevada and New Mexico. Look up castle bravo which was a nuclear test that irradiated the local area as well the Japan, the USA and even as far as Europe. The test site is encased in concrete to try and stop the radiation leaks and the concrete dome is failing. Nuclear isotopes are long lasting and dangerous to human life. Only a small number of large thermonuclear (fission followed by fusion) would be high enough from the radioactive plume to irradiate the planet

Uh this isn't quite accurate... the nuclear bomb uses nuclear fusion by crushing atoms together as close as possible until they reach critical mass and start splitting. This starts a chain reaction that continues to the next atom of refined radioactive material. The effectiveness of the bomb has been improved over the years by finding ways to get the atoms closer and contain the explosion within critical mass levels longer, so that when it explodes, it has a greater force of atoms reacting. All this is to say at that depth, assuming they somehow got the device to go that deep (it would crush itself and hit critical mass long before going that deep), it could very well destroy the entire world. The pressure would multiply the effectiveness of the bomb by as many atmospheres as it were deep, plus quite a bit extra. The atoms would be forced so close together, that it's nearly impossible to comprehend how devastating the bomb would be by the time it could break out of the inward pushing force. It would   be far more than what would be required to set off every volcano in the world and create 500+ foot tsunamis. The heated steam and volcanic debree would create a worldwide lightning storm that would create enough magnetic interference to short every electrical device that is powered. 90% of humanity would be burned alive within hours. The rest would perish from tsunamis, nuclear fallout, starving, extreme weather, or the resulting ice age.

I think it's totally wrong, because it failed to take into account the shock wave.
Fireballs of nuclear explosions stop growing not because "atmosphere pushes back", but because shock wave loses enough energy to stop ionizing and heating air to temperatures where it glows. But now transparent shock wave happily continues outward.
Watch Hardtack Umbrella underwater nuclear test video. Mere 8 kiloton explosion 50 meters down below threw 1.5 kilometer tall, relatively narrow column of water up. Fireball wasn't even visible, but the entire surface of water above the test location "jumped" and flew up (including now-pulverized former barge from which test device was hung on the cable) - this was done by the passage of the upward-going shock wave.
Zeroth-order approximation tells me that "similar" (to scale) effects with 50MT device would require depth of ~1km and would have a water column ~20 km high.
Deeper explosion at 11 km depth would be more similar to Operation Wigwam than to Umbrella: lower, wider, bowl-shaped spray dome.

This video is actually false and the "effects" has been refuted by nuclear physicists. Due to the pressure of the trench, the radiation of the bomb would be concentrated and once the blast energy has dissipated, the concentrated radiation would then spread and destroy ecosystems for hundreds of miles. Also the "pressure" wouldn't compare to the energy emitted from the 50 megatons worth of energy being released. The blast bubble would reach the surface of the water and explode upward causing huge oceanic disturbance for hundreds of miles. There may not be volcanos or costal city damage but the radiation alone would be enough cause vast damage to the ecosystems of ocean surface life.

Well, actually the Tsar bomb they tested was a "reduced power" prototype with the uranium of the third stage replaced with lead.
The final design was a three stage bomb, fission-fusion-fission.
Since there was no outer fission stage, and the inner one was boosted by the fusion of the second, the prototype of the Tsar bomb was one of the "cleanest" nuclear bomb ever tested (for its size).
In nuclear explosions most of the fallout comes from incomplete fission.

Interesting how they said that they consult experts to fact check their video...they said the oceans would be a radioactive soup but in reality, the tsar bomba was one of the cleanest thermonuclear weapons ever detonated. 97% percent of the explosive yield was produced by the fusion stage because they swapped out a uranium component with a lead one in essence preventing the 3rd fission stage from detonating. The Tsar bomba did not generate a shock wave that circled the earth three times. First of all, shock waves radiate from the blast, they do not circle anything else. Second, if it did "circle" the earth three times, we would all have noticed it very well indeed. There was, however, a seismic wave caused by the shock wave, which allegedly circled the earth three times. But at what latitude? The Tsar bomba was detonated north of the Polar circle, and the seismic wave was certainly not registered in South Africa. But could it circle the earth latitudinally? Sure it could, but at that particular latitude the earth is only about 10,000 miles around. So the seismic waves would travel about 5,000 miles before colliding and returning, for more than 30,000 miles, but less than 40,000 miles.

The Tsar Bomb (Big Ivan) did not have a fission booster stage which made its yield proportionally cleaner than any other thermonuclear device ever tested.  It was a prototype for a 100-150 Mt device.  No, there would not be much radiation from the 50 Mt version of the device.  That was dated technology by 1961 and nothing more than a spectacle used to scare the Americans.  The Mariana Trench is not a steep walled canyon and its true horizontal scale is not widely known.  It is formed mostly by grades of just a few percent that may run downward for many tens of miles.  Its horizontal scale is massive.  Shock waves would not be impacting against solid vertical rock walls as suggested by the animation.  Challenger deep, the deepest spot known at this time, is a small area 200 miles southwest of Guam.  The actual depression, most likely akin to a big mud hole is maybe a mile wide and seven miles long.  No living vertebrates (fish) have ever been found below 26,000 feet to date.  Biochemistry literally begins to change under that much pressure and it is no longer a simple matter of pressure inside canceling out the pressure on the outside of an organism.  Piccard and Walsh were not biologists and would not have known a fish from something else they might have seen while at the bottom of the Mariana Trench back in 1960.  Agreed, such a detonation would not amount to much.

Hmm, they talk about a fusion-based bomb (which is what the Tzar Bomb is: A hydrogen fusion bomb), but show how a fission-based (uranium/plutonium) bomb works. Also, a hydrogen bomb does not generate as much radioactive fallout as a fission based bomb.

Also, if the force could be applied below ground (near a sensitive point in the fault line), it could have some effect. Not a global effect, but some regional effect. The Tzar Bomb was rated at 50 megatons (50 million tons) of TNT. A 9.0 earthquake releases about 100 megatons of TNT equivalent energy. Because of the logarithmic nature of the Richter scale, the bomb explosion would probably be somewhere 8.3 on the scale.

The problem is getting the bomb into a useful position. The deepest drill hole know is 7.5 miles, and the deepest part of the trench is about 7 miles. A machine would have to be built to make a hole large enough to take the bomb down to the fault line (which will probably take at least 10 years and many millions of dollars). The operation would have to be done on one of the Marianas Islands (like Guam), so it's most likely not to remain a secret for very long.

The Cannikin underground test (1971) was a 5 megaton bomb that triggered a 7.0 earthquake on Amchitka Island (with 4.0 aftershocks for a few weeks after), so using an atomic weapon to generate an earthquake is feasible, but not necessarily practical.

Also, just because most of the 'force' of the blast would go up doesn't negate the fact that the shockwave from the blast would penetrate the sides of the Marianas trench and radiate into the earth over several miles. After all, both water and rock transmit shockwaves better than air does. If the circumstances are right, it could generate a number of aftershocks in excess of 5.0 on the Richter scale.

The destructive force of nuclear weapons doesn’t come from the fireball, it comes from the shockwave. The shockwave would travel much faster, and carry a lot more force a lot further underwater. It would probably kill most fish and marine mammals for thousands of miles. Kicking up that much sediment would probably turn a pretty big chunk of the pacific into a radioactive mud pit. And the massive column of superheated water is going to form a massive geyser when it breaches the surface. Miles high tidal waves? Probably not, but we’ve seen the kind of devastation that comes from tidal waves just a few meters high from earthquakes with less force.

There is possibly tensions in these continental plates that could be released (also without explosives).
If the plate is already very deep there with high tensions it could release some day a lot of energy without any warning and that could result into megatsunami. But the earthquake prediction is possibly very difficult science and there is hardly no measurement for the plate tension and movement in the depths of the ocean.
If the trench bottom jumps up by 30meters (in few seconds) by the earthquake that could cause a lot of problem. The penetration of the bottom sinking plate into the mantle is possibly very long like 1,000km with a lot of friction and thus large movements would not easily happen very fast. But the top sinking plate has its edge there and that edge could jump upwards when tensions released. Even the rock (what makes the plates) is not very strong material it could store a lot of energy like a piece of string.
It can be hard to say if plate edges that are deeper have thus more tensions or less tensions. If the plates are heated more (nearly melted) in the depths the heat could allow the tension to release continuously and bending to occur that does not store the energy as much as colder plates could store.

Scientist Kurchatov and others delayed the Soviet atom bomb, as indicated by bits and pieces of reseach materials on the Internet.
Racism also plays a role among scientists, as indicated by a few documents as researched on the Internet. The Soviet atom bomb program was started in 1936 or so. The scientists , predominantly from Russia and other nations, were spearheaded by Eagor Kurchatov, a brilliant and good-looking scientist. Everyone had a code name. Head scientist Kurchatov's code name was "Beard" or "Brown Beard". Kurchatov's secretary was "Miss Beard". Kurchatov along with his more famous dissident nuclear scientists and made the final blue prints of the atom bombs in the early 1940's. The team simply refused to ask for bomb materials to actally make the bomb. The Soviet Union was ruled by a Georgian named Joseph Stalin. Scientist Kurchatov and others delayed the Soviet atom bomb. Kurchatov and the other nuclear scientists were convinced that Stalin may immediately use the their atom bomb against Germany or Japan, as they felt that Stalin, an ethnic Georgian, may be a mad man. They only tested their atom bomb in 1949 under threats and duress from Moscow, who said "Enough is enough. Your Kurchatov team could have built the Soviet atom bomb in 1944. We want the bomb in 1949, before the decade of 1940's is out." They wrote, Otherwise You Soviet scientist comrades, consider yourselves fired, whether from your jobs as nuclear scientist or by a bullet to the head."" Scientist Kurchatov and others delayed the Soviet atom bomb. So, the Soviet atom bomb was delayed by 5 years. They wanted a Slav at the helm in power before giving the ready bomb to the Soviet leaders. Stalin was still in power in 1949.
The Soviet scientists were convinced that an ethnic non European leader will immediately use the atom bomb, and hence their attempt at delay. Guess what? they were right: An American president named Truman used the atom bomb, and he is a non European leader.

Conventional explosives were able to achieve similar results compared to nuclear weapons. They also test advanced sonar in this part of the world. Some suggest that the tested systems are so powerful that they cause many big whales to lose all sense of direction, hence all the strandings.

Slight issue with this; the Tsar Bomba was initially designed for a yield of 100 megatons but due to concerns over fallout, the dropping aircraft not being able to escape the blast, etc., the tamper (the cylinder which contains the fusion fuel) was changed from uranium in the initial design to lead.  This cut the yield by nearly half and also resulted in the Tsar Bomba being amongst the 'cleanest' nukes ever detonated with almost all of the yield coming from the fusion detonations.  As such, radioactivity would be minimal and given the sheer size of the ocean and the depths over which that radiation would travel before reaching the surface, radiation would be a minimal concern.

The Tzar Bomb was a hydrogen bomb and as such it used nuclear fusion not fission. Its called a "hydrogen" bomb because it fuses two isotopes of hydrogen into an atom of helium and the resulting reaction creates the energy. The uranium-235 creates a fission explosion to set off the fusion reaction. As such the fission is only the catalyst for the fusion reaction so to be exact, the hydrogen bomb is a nuclear fusion bomb.

While one bomb will do practically nothing, we've got a whole lot more than one bomb. The Cold War has seen to that. While it is laughable to think that the force created by all of our bombs is enough to destroy the planet directly, it is perhaps not so laughable to think that all of them would be enough to provide the catalyst to a world-ending chain reaction. All it needs to do is to be systematically detonated at a few key points -- perhaps split evenly three ways all the nuclear weapons of the world, one of them being in the Mariana trench perhaps and the other two being deep within volcanoes...

It is laughable to expect the summation of our weaponry to put anything more than a dent or massive crater on the surface of the planet if done in one place, yes. But that was never the point. All you would really have to do is send enough energy into the mantle at the right spots to create turmoil beneath the plates...

If a nuke like that went off under water it could easily kill every fish in the entire ocean.  Shockwaves travel through fluids without losing any energy, and only lose small amounts of energy when they come across pockets of gas and are able to compress them.  These pockets of gas which the shockwaves hit are nothing more than the lungs, hearts, and brains of the fish swimming around in the ocean.  And if you create a shockwave from a nuclear blast UNDERNEATH the ocean, you are asking for total disaster.  Watch the youtube video on "grenade underwater vs outside" or something like that.

"Pretty much nothing"?  That was the grand conclusion?  This guy obviously has no idea how fluids transfer pressure and shockwaves differently than gaseous air.  Lets just say, if a nuke went off underwater, every fish within a 2,000-mile radius will instantly die.  This video is incredibly misinformed.  There's a video on Youtube which discusses what would be more safe, having a grenade go off while underwater or having a grenade go off while outside.  I highly suggest you watch it.  There's a reason why throwing a M-80 in a pond will kill every fish.

If the Tsar Bomba was detonated at the bottom of the Mariana trench and still had enough power to vaporize approximately a one kilometer sphere then yes there would be second order consequences. For starters the trench would direct most of that energy up towards the surface. Just a one kilometer bubble would displace approximately one tenth the depth of the water In the trench. Between the pressure wave moving upward and the subsequent backfill of water there would indeed be massive waves produced. Raw math would predict a one kilometer tall initial wave but I expect that some of that height would be mitigated by expansion to the sides. Even if only a third of this energy emerged as discernable wave height we would still expect to see approximately 330 meter or close to 1000 foot waves. Also we could expect the trench to direct that energy up and then perpendicular to the trench.  I like your consideration of the raw pressures exerted at the trench floor but would love to see some math backing up your claim that it would likely and effectively negate the power of the bomb. Overall, very Interesting. Thank you.

I call BS.  The trench has walls.  And that massive pressure change would push on those walls.  The explosion is in every direction.  And, we know how volcanos happen.  Trapped pressure builds until it finds a way out... eruption.  I would argue that the pressure on the walls are already very high, just like right before a volcano erupts.  And just a slight bit of pressure (the last drop in a bucket causes the water to spill) and we know the Mariana Trench is from the crust moving/plates shifting.  So, if we were to add so much energy/pressure we could be that last bit of pressure that causes enables the shift to be severe.  And, we also know pressure on solid material, like the trench walls, are barely absorbed but actually transferred through the material under it finds an outlet... like, an eruption.  If you drop a grenade into a pool and have inflated balloons secured to the opposite side of the pool wall or bottom (to simulate a human’s body/lungs) the explosive force pressurized the water and those balloons or a human body will be crushed/burst.  I agree that the pressure of that depth would be significant enough to diminish the explosive force above the destination point but the explosive force is in every direction, 3D.  This theory may be true and I would accept that it is somewhat likely but I wouldn’t bet all life on it.  Fracking is already causing earthquakes/tremors and that’s just because they pressurize an gas-filled pocket to force the gas up and out.  And, I fear that fracking may causes eruptions.  Eruptions are mostly caused by water favor/steam pressure finding a way out and then after the eruption, the liquid magma has a way out, too.  Yellowstone Park is actually a huge volcanic field.  The geysers release the pressure at a significant rate that the pressure does not become eruption-worthy.  But, Old Faithful is no longer faithful and other areas of the park are becoming more active.  If the geysers somehow no longer relieve the pressure, say because more water is pumped into the earth and turns to steam, Yellowstone could become a huge volcano and erupt.  So much ash that the farmlands in the Midwest are no longer producing and enough very small ash/dirt erupted into the sky that we experience less sunlight reaching the surface.  And the eruption would have enough force that it would make Tsar Bomba seems harmless.  Fault lines, especially in the US, would break apart.  Bye bye most of California.  I am a pessimist and we are all, by nature.  We fear and worry about the negatives for survival.  And this video/theory is very incomplete.

Just so you all know, I specify neutron radiation because that is the only kind that makes affected atomic structures radioactive as well.

I read recently that almost half of the oxygen in our atmosphere is created by phytoplankton in the oceans. I've been wondering... what affect would nuclear fallout have on the phytoplankton?

In the scenario you have described here the effect would probably be limited, but I'm wondering about the effect more generally. Would fallout from a nuclear war kill the phytoplankton and deprive us of a key source of oxygen thus adding one more very nasty outcome to a scenario already filled with very nasty outcomes?

If the nuclear explosions, radiation, fallout, and nuclear winter don't kill us, would the lack of oxygen?

Also, how much oxygen would all of those massive nuclear explosions and the resulting fires consume? What proportion of the Earth's oxygen would get consumed in the initial round of a nuclear war?

When doing atomic bomb test in the year... I don't know, we realized it wasn't good for the air quality. We dug a huge pit and blew up the bomb. nothing was affected too dramatically except a manhole that we used to seal the hole. If vanished completely! We had no idea what happened to it until we decided to test this again. we used an extremely efficient camera to record what happened. In one frame, the manhole was there. two frames later, it was gone. In the frame in between, however, there was a small corner of it visible on the top of the screen. We used the power of math to find out that the manhole cover was shot up into space. Those two manhole covers are the fastest man-made objects, not a spaceship or satellite, just two manhole covers.

The Tsar bomb was estimated at various strengths, but the most common number is 50 megatons, not the 1 megaton (of TNT) shown in the graphic at 4:30. The 1906 earthquake in San Francisco has been updated to ~7.9 on the Richter scale, or 4.5 x 10^16 Joules. One megaton (of TNT) is 4.2x10^15 Joules. This puts the San Francisco quake at ~10 megatons, so the 4:30 graphic got that right. I'll have to ask a nuke colleague if the 1 megaton (for the Tsar bomb) shown here was some modification of the energy released, as a result of being under 1,086 atmospheres. I know chemical explosions, but DK if nuclear ones might be moderated in this way. Maybe. Seems that if anything compression should increase the yield by increasing the fraction of the fuel that fuses.

In typical year, the Pacific tectonic plate moves about 1-2 cm.
The estimated mass of all that rock, magma and water is on the order of trillions of tons.
The energy it takes to move the plate is equally immense.
It would take around 15000 Tzar-Bomba, the biggest nuke ever made, to approximate the energy of one year of plate-shift.
And that's jut the Pacific.
Reference:
Mt. St. Helens, 1980, blew off about 1/4 of its volume in a blast that was estimated to be around 24 megatons.
Watch the video of the blast: the dirt and rocks sort of heave, then slide down one side of the mountain.
Hardly the show a planet-ending bomb should have had, amirite?
This mountain could completely hide in any of the deep trenches, BTW.
Toggle a nuke in a trench, you get some earthquakes, some sloppy-water events on the shore-line, and not much else.
Reference:
Hurricane Katrina, at peak power, was dumping around a megaton of energy per minute!
Megatons per minute. Hour after hour.
A 'typical' hurricane dumps around 10,000 'Hiroshima' units of energy during its life-span.
Yeah, nukes are terrible 'from a certain point of view', but Earth and Sky are so much bigger than our small machines.

I happen to know a LOT more detail, and here it is.
In the 60s, the government secretly exploded a very deep nuke, and they instrumented the hell out of it. They also did it with huge conventional explosions. The analysis (written in the 70s) is now unclassified. Being curious (and working at a nuc engineering place), I read it.

First of all, an amazing fact: Despite being in direct contact with a nuclear explosion, the water of the expanding bubble wall does not boil! The pressure inside the bubble exceeds (by far) the vapor pressure of water. The water touching the blast can only boil during contraction of the bubble after it expands.

A deep (> half mile) underwater nuclear explosion leaves no trace at the surface but hot, radioactive water rising from below. There are no bubbles because they were collapsed in the deep water and the gas inside them got dissolved into the water.

At its maximum diameter, a very large nuclear bomb creates a bubble about a half-mile wide in about one second. But the expansion quickly becomes unsustainable because the amount of water pushed outward increases with the CUBE of the blast-bubble radius.

Then it quickly collapses because:

► Deep water pressure is enormous. It is the weight of the water above the explosion.

► The expansion reduces gas pressure, which decreases temperature.

► Water is not compressible like sponge, styrofoam, wood, rock, or even solid metal. Water is nearly incompressible. Because of this, compressing that much of it that fast absorbs a truly righteous amount of energy.

► Vast amounts of energy are also absorbed by phase change (water becomes steam).

► Rayleigh–Taylor instability at the gas/water boundary causes "fingers" of water to extend into the bubble, increasing the boundary surface area, cooling the gas.

In about a second, the water pressure outside the bubble causes it to collapse back into a small sphere with very high gas pressure. This also takes one second. Then it rebounds, expanding again. This is repeated several times (3 or 4), but each rebound contains only about 40% of the energy of the previous cycle.

Blast bubbles from deep nuclear explosions become mere hot water in about six seconds and leave no small bubbles to float up to the surface.

This drastic loss of energy between cycles is caused in part by the extreme force of a nuclear explosion pushing the bubble wall outward supersonically (faster than the speed of sound in saltwater). The speed causes Rayleigh–Taylor instability. That is, the smooth inner wall surface becomes turbulent and fractal, with fingers and branches of cold ocean water extending into the bubble. That cold water cools the hot gas inside and causes it to condense. The bubble becomes less of a sphere and looks more like the Crab Nebula, the deviation of which from a smooth surface is also due to Rayleigh–Taylor instability.

Boiling in the contracting bubble acts like evaporation, cooling the bubble wall, and it is another reason that an oscillating blast bubble contains only 40% of the energy it had in the previous cycle.

During these hot gas oscillations, the bubble rises. This causes the blast bubble never to be perfectly spherical. Instead, the bottom of the bubble is flatter, and during contraction, it even tends to "reach up" toward the blast center.

In the last contraction cycle, the bottom of the bubble touches the top before the sides have fully collapsed, and the bubble becomes a torus in its last second of life. After six seconds, all that remains of a large nuclear explosion is a mass of hot water, slowly rising from the cold depths of the ocean.

Yes! Thankyou! A video displaying actual science instead of overblown nonsense. While the energy of a large hydrogen bomb is incredible, it is indeed tiny compared to the energy of natural occurrences on Earth. The total moment energy (not surface energy) of a large earthquake like a 9.0 is equivalent to over 5 teratons of TNT. Orders of magnitude larger than our entire nuclear arsenal let alone one bomb. The tectonic plates are massive and can not be affected by an explosion. And the Earths orbit? The Chicxulub Asteroid 65 million years ago hit with thousands of times the energy of the worlds entire nuclear arsenal combined. And yet it failed to change the Earths orbit.

Actually, because the Tsar Bomba was a three stage hydrogen fusion bomb, it was so efficient compared to American designs that it barely produced any radioactive particles at all. Greater yet, it was not 1 megatons: it was 50 megatons and designed for 100 but reduced with collateral damage possible.

Going to have to disagree with you on this one. Your assumption is that a bubble of vapor is going to sit at the bottom of the trench and get compressed, when in fact the bubble would be pushed toward the surface by the greater pressure underneath it. It may take a while to reach the surface, but it would still throw a huge amount of gases into the sky. The resulting water shockwave would create quite a large tsunami.
Also, a bomb of that magnitude could trigger a seismic event depending on the pressure already present in the fault line.

Hang on, I think there'd be more than just bubbles.

As air and water are both fluids, the expanding blast would behave the same in both, although (as the vid said) wouldn't expand as far underwater due to the much higher pressure. But I see no reason why there wouldn't be an outward push of the water, followed by the quick rush of the pushed out water back to the center, just as we see happen in with air on the surface. This expanding would push water out (which continue to the water's surface) and may become a giant wave. OR, it's the rapid rush of water to fill the void left by the explosion would create it's own shock wave, just like how when someone bomb dives, it's not the impact which creates the largest wave, it's water rushing back in and colliding which does.

If course seeing as the trench i so deep, perhaps the energy wouldn't reach the surface.

Or, instead of pushing out the water, it just gets vaporised, in which case, you'd still have a void that the water would quickly rush back in to fill.

So, a question.  Proton-proton fusion is probably not a viable pathway, despite the density of protium in water, given its extremely small probability of occurring for any given interaction, but would it be at least hypothetically possible to initiate a proton-deuterium chain reaction in Earth’s oceans, triggering a runaway fusion reaction (which, given the volume of the ocean and the quantity of deuterium therein, would trivially release enough energy to vaporize Earth and probably the Moon as well)?  From what (clumsy, amateurish) calculations I’ve been able to make, given the known concentration of deuterium in seawater, the answer seems to be yes, but with the caveat that even the Tsar Bomba’s energy was about a hundredfold too small to actually initiate such a reaction.  My own unfamiliarity with the science in question, though, and my inability to find any papers specifically addressing the topic (there were some very educational papers looking at the fusion of nitrogen in the atmosphere, but nothing specifically addressing the energetics of an aquatic detonation), leaves me very suspicious of my result.

Firstly, I'm assuming that the earth is split in two hemispheres and we are trying to separate those. I'm only considering gravitational force, otherwise the problem would be too complicated. By integration I found that the center of mass of each hemisphere is 3R8 away from the center, so the distance between the two centers of mass is 6R8.

Most equals (=) mean approximately equal to (≈), but because the method to calculate this force is already a huge approximation, it won't really matter.

GMmR6R8=6.67×10−11 m3⋅kg−1⋅s−2=5.97×1024 kg=M2=2.99×1024 kg=6.37×106 m=4.78×106 m
Newton's Law of Gravitation:

F=Gm2r2=2.61×1025 N
which is: 2.610.000.000.000.000.000.000.000 Newtons which is 2 septilions and 610 sextillion or something hahaha

That's the force each of those hemispheres exerts on the other, so to separate them, you would need a force larger than this value.

NEW: I'll add to these calculations the amount of energy necessary to separate these two hemispheres in a way that they wouldn't pull each other and be together again.

U=Gm2r=1.25×1032 joule which is HUGE.

Just for you to have an idea, the sun releases 3.85×1026 J per second of energy in the form of light. You would need all the energy that the sun releases over a period of 3.76 days (assuming you weren't losing any, which is almost impossible).

Really cool :D

New 2: According to Wikipedia, the Earth receives 174 petawatts at the upper atmosphere, which is 1.74×1017 W.

To gather enough energy to blow the planet apart, one would need to save all the energy that hits the Earth for 7.18×1014 s, which is 23100000 years. Don't forget that people need energy to live and that it's almost impossible to manage to gather all of it.

So... maybe someday :D

For the most part, this is a factually decent video. You forgot there'd be plasma formed, too. :)

But I'm not so sure about the tsunamis. Granted, they probably wouldn't be catastrophic, but when you have sudden 1 km void, it will probably oscillate few times (cavitation effect included) and that will propagate to the surface. Near the shores, a tiny displacement from the point right above the explosion would grow considerably. How much, that's a matter of complicated calculations, but I fear it would not be a laughing matter.

Calculations get really complicated when you include the compressibility of water. Mariana's trench would be some 15 m deeper if water wasn't compressible.

Also, it's really called "Tsar". Not "Tsar bomba". "Bomba" is not part of its name, it's just bomb in Russian. Yes, I know Wikipedia says it, but in this case, as in many others, there's a vocal majority that presents a disinformation and it sticks, pouring all over the Internet, until a disinformation becomes a factoid.

With a 1 km diameter, the sphere would have a volume that would raise the average ocean volume by something like 1 micrometer, or one millionth of a meter. Near the original explosion, it might be slightly more of a rise, but if the detonation were this deep it would be essentially nothing.

The energies involved with nuclear weapons are definitely impressive, but they are nothing compared to tectonic activity, or natural forces in general. A hurricane alone releases an amount of energy that is about equivalent to all of the nuclear weapons on the planet (in that ballpark) throughout its lifetime, assuming said weapons were all detonated at once.

Then again a nuclear weapon can be far more "deadly" for what it does. Since in the case of a hurricane, much of the energy is simply being dispersed into the atmosphere, and an earthquake mostly into the deep ground as opposed to the surface. A nuclear weapon on the other hand, if detonated in close proximity and in open air, creates a massive shockwave of compressed air that does most of the real damage. Of course the heat and radiation are also significant, but not in terms of immediate damage.

Couple things worth mentioning that I'm quite surprised they didnt explain:
The bubble it is describing is a giant cavitation bubble. The water causes it to collapse and bounce back out, but instability causes it to be less effective. It would look EXACTLY like it does in the slowMo guys video where they fire a gun underwater.
Water is a good radiation absorber, so radiation wouldnt travel and wouldnt last long. That's why nuclear power plants use pools of water to store waste.
There is no sea life at the deepest point of the marianas trench. The pressure is too great for many organics compounds to form and be stable. No sea life will be harmed by the detonation of a nuclear bomb at the deepest part of the ocean.

comment_by: Ha ha, He he, Ho ho
comment_text: ...except the fact that that much of radioactive waste and subsequent fallout will irreversibly pollute water, air and land 😛

Some things:

Early testing proved that bombs (atomic or conventional) are lousy tsunami creators. The ideal tsunami creator creates a permanent (or at least one that lasts hours) displacement in the water measured in cubic miles. A large bomb creates a bubble (a cavitation bubble, containing steam, not air) that expands against the pressure and then collapses, rebounds outward to a smaller diameter, collapses again, and continues the cycle until all the potential/kinetic energy is converted into heat. That will create waves close in but not the long-period waves that are tsunamis.

Under huge pressure not even a bubble will be created. Water is NOT incompressible, only relatively so compared to air. If it were totally incompressible, it would not be able to transmit sound, which is a pure compression waveform. Nothing I know of is totally incompressible, even neutronium in neutron stars transmits shock waves.

Underwater bomb experiments:
Crossroads/Baker - in 50 meters inside the Bikini lagoon, 20 kT.
Wigwam - in 610 meters of water in the Pacific Ocean, 400 miles off LA, 30 kT.
Hardtack I/Wahoo - in 150 meters outside Bikini Lagoon, 9 kT.
Hardtack I/Umbrella - in 50 meters inside the lagoon, 9 kT.
Dominic/Swordfish - in 198 meters in the Pacific Ocean, ASROC test, undisclosed yield.
USSR #22 (Joe 17) - in 12 meters at Novaya Zemlya, 3.6 kT. (these three USSR tests were torpedo tests)
USSR #48 (Joe 42) - in 20 meters at NZ, 10 kT.
USSR #122 (Koral-1, Joe-117) - in 58 meters at NZ, 4.8 kT.
That's the complete list of underwater tests. All the US tests and the USSR #22 are featured in videos on YT.

Radioactivity generated by the bomb is not a hazard. First, there is no life as we know it in the trench. No energy. No smokers (they work at plate spread joints, not subduction), no sunlight, no currents, no nothing. Secondly, water is a very good shield from radioactivity. 6 meters is enough to lower the worst radioactivity we have (fresh spent reactor fuel) to background. Third, nothing to spread the radioactivity around. Too deep and protected from even the deepest circulation currents. All material from the bomb will drop no farther from the blast than, say, a mile. No bubble to the surface (too much pressure).

Oops: it appears that I am wrong about life in the trench. OK, scratch that argument.

Just a quick opinion here! Feel free to keep scrolling! This is meant in the most constructive way possible but I felt it should be said! I personally feel that a noticeable amount of your (Kurzgesagt) videos have a bit of a political bias (not this one, it's just the most recent). While you are completely entitled to your views, and even though I agree with a fair bit of them, I personally would like to see that this channel be a bit more clear cut and less bias if possible. While there will always be some trace amount of bias, I do feel that it could definitely be lessened for the sake of raw information. This all being said, I have yet to dislike a single video, and if nothing were to change I would not be hurt one bit. I just find that sometimes bias can cloud up the information, and especially make it hard for some to differentiate from what is the creators opinion, and what is fact. All that aside, keep it up, your channel is amazing! Cheers!

Regarding the whole "natural disasters are so much more powerful than nuclear weapons" thing: while this is true in a sense, not only are nukes a more concentrated release of particularly dangerous energy, unlike earthquakes and hurricanes they also release said energy almost instantaneously. The fission-fusion reaction of Tsar Bomba only lasted 39 nanoseconds, but in that moment it released roughly 1% of the energy the entire SUN would produce over the same time frame IIRC.

Tsar Bomba was one of the cleanest nuclear explosions on record in terms of fallout. It had lead casing to stop fast neutrons and avoid ternary fission reaction and most of its yield was due to deuterium-tritium fusion (which does not create any particularly radioactive products besides neutrons which will happily brake in water). So your whole dance around the radioactive plumes etc is inaccurate at best and misleading at worst. Most of the effects would boil down to creating a few tons of heavy water via neutron irradiation, some radioactive sediment from "starter" fission charge (no more than 10 metric tonnes), a little bit of radioactive Krypton (no more than 50 kg according to a back-of-the-envelope calculation, which is just 8 cubic meters under normal conditions), and quite a bit of your garden-variety helium-4 (ionized). Almost all of the radioactive materials, with the exception of Krypton, will stay at the bottom of the sea. Also, tell your animator that illustrating a thermonuclear fusion-type bomb with a fission reaction is more than a bit misleading -- while a smaller fission bomb is used to start a fusion reaction, it's not where most of the yield comes from, not by a long shot.

The shockwave, though harmless to Earth, will probably do quite a bit of harm to the surrounding sea creatures.
Water is nearly incompressible and as a result the shockwave rapidly blows outwards at mach 5.
Anything in the way will experience the same force as crashing into a wall of water at five times the speed of sound.
This normally wouldn't be a big deal as regular explosives generate thin shockwaves, but a nuclear shockwave can be extremely thick. So thick that the wall of water might as well be rubber.

"Why?" you may ask? as a developer myself I truly believe in the power of my audience and without their support I wouldn't be where I am. If it wasn't for any of us, you wouldn't be where you are now. I respect your decision and if that's what you want to do, fine, but to accept it is a different *opinion*. Something seems weird about this. If the bubble was a kilometer across, and assuming it is a perfect hemisphere (bottom of the ocean prevents a full sphere) then it would displace about approximately 2.09 cubic km of water. To maintain volume, the rest of the hemisphere would need to increase to 11.002 km in size. That is a 2 m wave in the deepest part of the ocean. Tsunamis in open ocean create smaller waves than that. And if it moved that much water in one second, the wave would be moving at 1 km a sec or 2200 mph. That kinda seems dangerous to me...

Still not happy with the explanation of pressure at depth...

Your animation suggests that a chicken would be compressed into an unrecognizable sphere of goo, which is very far from reality. being at depth is NOT like being crushed by a hydraulic press from every direction, it's like being underwater at very high pressure. Any compressible materials will be compressed, and a few chemical reactions in your body will change because molecules interact differently at higher pressure, but the majority of materials in animals, people, in fact the majority of solids are in-compressible. The chicken in the example will have the air in its lungs squeezed down to the size of a pin-head, which will probably cause some mechanical damage to the alveoli, and it will obviously suffocate. However, otherwise, it will still look like a chicken as it falls into the abyss.

This is a surprisingly common misconception, as we saw in the other (unnamed) video.

Assuming that your thought experiment is using the 50MT version of the Tsar Bomba that was tested on the Russian archipelago Novaya Zemlya, then there would be little to no radioactive fallout, as that version used a lead tamper and got ~99% of its energy from hydrogen fusion. But, if your thought experiment uses the planned and canceled 100MT version of the Tsar Bomba that used a depleted uranium tamper, then your thought experiment is 100% accurate, as that version would have created immense amounts of radioactive fallout.

The Fallout of the a nuke going off in the ocean would be far more extreme the one going off on land. The Radio fallout would be deadly to life and would spread through the oceans quickly. It would make most complex life sick, but would kill off most tiny organisms like krill and and tiny photosynthetic plants  floating around in the jet streams. This would spread all over one if not all of our oceans eventually. The Radio active fallout would delude once spread enough around our oceans and maybe its low enough for life to survive. Sadly this won't be true for the ocean the detention happens. In a week or two we would see lots of dead marine life within 1000km.  Everything from Whales, to tiny fish would be floating around dead having  the base of their food chain demolished to a extreme degree, effectively starving to death. Predator animals wouldn't starve so easily, thye may just get sick from eatting radio active fish, but they would leave seeking other prey in other oceans. This would drastically change the ecosystem of that ocean It would effect us humans that much but it will me less fish food will be on the table for awhile. As for the fun idea of a nuke going off in the ocean causing something else more awesome to happen, the Answer is no, No Big Waves , Earthquakes or Storms will happen but we will get a damaged Ecosystem and we wouldn't see the effects until it is too late.

Something strikes me as inaccurate about this video. Firstly, in the description of the initial blast, only a nuclear fission reaction is described, which is in fact only the primer for the fusion of hydrogen which causes the main thermonuclear explosion in a bomb this size.

Later, when comparing the seismic energy of the bomb to earthquakes, the Tsar Bomba is labeled as having a 1 Mt blast, while the actual energy of the bomb was over 50 Mt, twice that of the Indian Ocean Earthquake. Granted, far from all the energy would go into seismic impact, but surely it's got to be more than a fiftieth of the blast energy, right?

I sense disturbing amounts apathetic levels of nihilism, who are we to say that nothing in this universe, whether it be humanity or the concept of life itself, doesn't matter or has a purpose? Outside the context of religious scripture or Philosophy, how could we make such judgment?
Because if human life indeed doesn't matter? Why bother trying to survive? why bother advancing ourselves in technology or society?

Because "just" and "only" the chemicals in our brain make us want to create a better living and to avoid death? Sure, it would be that way if you believe the chemicals in your brain that convince you that they are "just" and "only" chemicals, or that chemicals are intrinsically lesser than the concept of some "soul."
You could say that Earth is the only life-bearing planet or one of unmeasurable many, but either way, we do not know, and to question whether the abundance or lack of life, does it make matter the individual existence thereof? Does the intentional torture, or killing of even a single being whatever it is, matter? Then why not torture or kill everything around us because it doesn't matter? Why not kill ourselves?
Again, brain chemistry. Either way, we are designed upon ourselves to think about ourselves and consequently others, whether you believe in altruism or not, doesn't matter to me, in my opinion, there's nothing wrong with that.

As for the matter of the weapons themselves, you can say using a nuclear weapon does nothing compared the grand scale of the entire universe, but a galactic scale is not what we are dealing with on Earth. So it does always matter, whenever we do test these weapons, modify them, and actively use them with intent to destroy.

This is great, except it kind of makes it sound like nuclear weapons are no big deal compared to nature (in the same way that some people claim human CO2 emissions are laughable compared to the sheer size of Earth’s atmosphere and therefore cannot possibly be causing any harm; indeed, many people will draw a direct comparison in their minds, if not out loud) By implication, this makes it sound like Nuclear War would destroy a lot of individual cities but not really be that bad . In the current political climate (in America at least) this seems like a very dangerous idea to accidentally seen to promote. Can you do another video about how bad nuclear war would be, a la the excellent BBC Docudrama “Threads” or the long term terrifyingly widespread effects of “Cobalt-enhanced nuclear bombs”, which cause a huge fallout zone that’s deadly radioactive for decades or more, not just years. In particular, the part in this video about thousands of nuclear weapons being detonated and the implication that “Earth is still fine” will lead many people to suddenly think that everything they have heard about the dangers of radiation and fallout were just overblown, and that nuclear weapons aren’t all that scary. Please make another video ASAP to re-emphasize the horrors of nuclear weapons so that credible people won’t suddenly think that deploying them is okay because a cartoon said so.

Kurzgesagt, some feedback. The quality of your videos is better than ever, and the way you explain stuff is still top notch, but I don't think hypothetical topics and scenarios like this one get me the same way that your informative, theoretical and factual videos do (like the one on how your body fights off infections). Your videos on ebola, black holes, and other real things just have so much interesting content in them that you do such a good job of explaining, and while this video was still dope, it doesn't give me the same feeling as learning about some real 'thing' that makes me say "fuck me, that's insane!" the same way that learning about how the immune system works. Hypothetical like this are cool, but I recon you should keep the content to things that are relative and very interesting - something you've been an absolute master of making videos about. Keep it up!

I hate to say this as I am such a big Cody fan, but your video is definitely better than his.

The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami released an estimated 26 megatons of energy. The vast majority of that energy went into moving the crust while a megathrust moved the water. Had it been a strike-thrust movement there would have been an insignificant tsunami.

The hypothetical Tsar bomb in the Marianna trench would release the vast majority of its energy into the water in a motion very similiar to a megathrust plate movement. While I agree it will not break the surface of the water it will rapidly raise then lower the water column. That can't help but produce a very large tsunami.

I think it would be fair to mention though that the tsar bomb is not the biggest bomb possible. Since it was a fusion bomb, you could theoretically have kept adding fuel, which was not done in the past, because for atmospheric detonations there is an upper efficiency level, after which the detonation energy escapes into space.
If you detonate it in the deep sea, this threshhold does not matter though, so one could build a far bigger bomb to detonate there.
